description:
Kings of the Castle is a moderate complexity level war game simulation of the climactic battle fought along the Imjin River during the Korean War.  Players draw formation activation markers to determine what units activate, and a six sided die ro resolve combats (air and artillery strikes as well as combat between opposing ground units), as well as other game events.

A complete game of Kings of the Castle is composed of the following:

•    One rules booklet
•    Two 11" by 17" maps
•    325 un-mounted, single-sided counters
•    Two players’ aid sheets with charts, tables, and record-keeping tracks.

Note that players will need to provide one 6-sided die and an opaque container (cup, envelope, etc.) to play the game.

Each night turn of the game represents two hours of time; day turns represent 4 hours.  Each hex is approximately one third of a mile across. Allied Infantry and both sides’ Heavy Weapons units represent companies (about 200 to 250 men). Chinese infantry units represent battalions (about 800 men). Allied armor/tank units represent 10-12 armored fighting vehicles.

-description from designer

It’s a wonderful lazy morning and your stomach is grumbling. What’s that heavenly smell coming from the kitchen? It’s Waffle Time! Draft combinations of fruit toppings and whipped cream to load up your waffle. Create patterns to spread syrup for scoring points. What you draft not only affects your score, but also your turn order and how much syrup you can use. After eight quick rounds, the player with the highest scoring waffle is the winner!

—description from the publisher

Can you fill all the tiles with pictures? Or maybe you will choose a more difficult variant of the game and be the one who finds the card depicting the biblical story you are reading the fastest?

This smart and colorful game will make you spend your time well and while having a great time, you will learn the stories of people who met the Lord Jesus.

The goal is to determine which description describes which image. You win if you have full sets of paintings.

CDSK is a trivia game that asks you to be honest with yourselves. How well do you know this subject? Too confident? You won’t go anywhere. Too careful? You’ll be crawling. But if you answer just right… you’ll zoom off to glorious victory!

Draw a card matching the space you’re on. Then move your piece as far forward as the difficulty you set… if you get the answer right!

—description from the publisher

In the world of Savage Bowl, anything's game. Late hits, excessive celebrations, cheap shots, crushing tackles, bribing the officials — do anything you can to score in the flashiest way!

While surviving all this carnage, your goal in Savage Bowl is to win an exact number of tricks (based on the player count). Play cleverly as the ref can penalize you for being too savage. In the first half of the game, they give yellow card penalties to the highest-value cards in each trick, then the second most valuable player wins the trick. The carded player also has to sit out the next round!

In the second half, the ref's had enough and anything goes — no more yellows.

Savage Bowl is a must-follow trick-taking game with five suits (numbered 1-13) and a trump suit (numbered 1-8). Score only if you win the correct number of tricks.

Dungeon Exit is a solo or two-player duel mode logic game.

In Dungeon Exit, the goal is to find a path from the door to the exit of the dungeon, passing by the key, the chest, and then the monster.
In solo mode, solve all the levels one by one, progressively.
With 2 players, be the fastest to find a path to win the game.

Optimize the placement of your tiles to find the path to the dungeon exit. The tiles must connect only at their ends by one and only one side of a square to form a path. Ready to take on the challenge?

The scenario of "Blitz Poland" in the game tried its best to restore the crushing trend of the German army in history. The unique combat mechanism and fast-paced advancement speed (in a lightning-fast way, the duration of a single round is shorter), which strengthened the attacking experience of German players, enough for players to experience the fun of the Blitz game.

During the game, players can support, move and fight in each turn. It allows players to experience the joy of restraining each other. Whether it is a strong attack on a point or a siege to aid, as long as it is a tactic you can think of, you can experience it in this miniature war and plan a strategy!

The game also sets up imaginary scripts and entertainment confrontation scenarios, and also supports single-player solo scenario to meet the psychological needs of mass players.

—description from the publisher (translated)

In Bone Wars, players take on the role of a palaeontologist in the late 1800s. During this time, a bitter rivalry was waged between Othniel Marsh and Edward Cope, two world-renowned palaeontologists. They both tried to outdo the other in discovering new species of dinosaurs, going so far as to bribe workers, steal or even destroy bones. The players are palaeontologists working for one of these legendary men or are perhaps working on their own behalf – trying to outdo all competition.

During the game, players have to make clever use of their action cards, which they play in the slots under their player board. These action cards can either activate their team - digging up fossils and discovering new species in the field - or their paleontologist - who spend their time publishing species, debunking other players' papers and getting awards.

Published species cards are added to bonus slots at the top of your player board. Each added species card gives a bonus depending on how many species cards are already in that specific slot.

When your paleontologist publishes a paper, it is added to either Marsh's or Cope's side, depending on which side the player is working for. Specific actions will also reward loyalty points with your current patron. At the end of the game, players multiply the number of loyalty they have (both with Marsh and Cope) with the published papers to gain VP. Published papers, therefore, count for all players. It is up to you to make them count the most for yourself.

-description from designer

Millenniums have passed.  The Nisblitts, aliens not of our dimension, have discovered the remains of humanity and all of earth's other ancient relics.  In order to study the emotions of these bizarre humans, the Nisblitts have revived one of these creatures and attached its mind to a device filled with fragments of 21st century language.  The only problem... they didn't realize that they had actually revived a Tyrannosaurus rex.

Players will take turns becoming this talking Emotional rex that must speak sentences in emotional ways.  The Nisblitt players will then assess these emotions with their data tokens.  Correct guesses on the emotion award points for both the Nisblitt players and the E-rex player.  The player with the most points at the end of the game knows what it truly means to be "human".

Rolling to the Elections is a roll and write game based on draft mechanics and dice rolling to obtain majorities. The game is designed for two players, although it supports a solitaire or multiplayer game mode.
 In Rolling to the Elections, each player play for being the president of a country by taking the role of one of the two candidates, either from the left-wing or the right-wing . To win the game, the player must obtain the majority of seats in the parliament.

There are five versions of the game: Spain ("Rolling to La Moncloa"), Germany ("Rolling to Kanzleramt") France ("Rolling to Elysee"), United Kingdom (Rolling to Downing Street) and USA (Rolling to the White House). In each version different rules are applied, adapted to the electoral model of each country and its regions, and they can be played independently.

—description from the designer

In Forest of "Number Spirits", players fulfill contracts by placing certain patterns onto the forest map (such as forest cubes, rock squares, or water ovals).  The fulfillment of the contracts grants the players special effects and lets them cross of certain digits on their bingo cards.  Players earn points by completing bingos and certain contracts.

The game takes place over two rounds and the player with the most points at the end of the second round wins.

Exordium is a 2 player, 3X (Explore / Examine / Extract) board game comprised of multi-use cards.  Players are part of the Exordium Expedition, studying the exoplanet and its Artifact; a towering piece of architecture that may be biological, or the work of some forgotten species.

Players will Explore by placing Outposts on the board, Examine by sending Drones to the Artifact, and Extract resources from the Terrain they’ve explored, gaining points for each. The player with the most points at the end of the game wins.

Exordium is a board game that uses cards in place of other components.

LUCRE is a trick taking card game for 4 players.  The nameless Guilds care about one thing: coins.  Each player controls a single Guild, and will play cards from their Guild deck (13 cards, each with a Value of 1-13 and worth 1-3 coins, each with no Value and 1 coin on the back) in an attempt to acquire more coins.

Each game, the 8 Purse cards are seeded randomly from each player’s Guild deck, meaning that every game, the Purse cards and the Guild cards available to each player will be different.  At the end of 8 rounds, the player with the most coins wins.

The King is dead, and you and your friends try to claim the empty throne. You will be fighting for the crown through various rounds. The goal is to score the highest points by the end of the round and claim the coveted crown.

In Crown Battles: Claim the Throne, players face different goals each round, such as completing missions or forming alliances. Special Ability cards add strategic depth, offering actions like stealing coins or changing the trump suit. The player with the highest score at the end is crowned the ultimate sovereign.

In Dwarves: The Fall of Karnarak, you incarnate a dwarf clan leader. In order to protect your home, the famous citadel of Karnarak, you must collaborate with the other clan leaders against a powerful dragon trying to take it.

Among clan leaders, you discuss and decide a plan of action, always taking into account the special abilities of each clan, and the functions of each room of the citadel. During the siege, events that can affect your plans will happen, often for the worse.

75 EVENT CARDS: Destabilise your strategy, make spawns appear or siege engin threaten your citadel
60 SPAWN CARDS: Make enemies appear way too close for comfort
60 TROOP CARDS: Allow you to fight the spawns
60 RESSOURCE CARDS: Allow you to buy upgrades, specialists, beer, divine intervention, or forge special items
8 SPECIALIST CARDS: Allow you to work better
8 UPGRADE CARDS: Allow the citadel to work better
5 CLAN LEADERS: Your identity for the game
5 WARLORDS: Your sworn enemies, soon to be defeated hopefully.
1 MAP OF THE CITADEL: Your board, and your home

Defend the fortress against hordes of enemies, upgrade your citadel, hire specialists in your clan, and above all, try to defeat the dragon, together.

Dioses del Nilo is a strategic and tactical board game for two players based on Egyptian mythology. The objective of each player is to defeat their opponent by skillfully moving their pieces on the board.

How to play?

The game is divided into two phases: the placement phase and the combat phase.

Each player's field is divided into two: vanguard and rearguard.

Each player must make a movement in each phase in an orderly manner and alternate with the opponent.

Placement phase:
In this phase the players both take 2 tiles from their tile column (the bottom two tiles). Then in turn (starting with the one with the clock on their side of the field) Place a token inside the field on any space you want.

Tokens that are placed in the rear can be placed face down.
Tiles placed in the vangauard are always placed face up.
Once a player places a token, he passes the other player's turn by sliding the clock card to the other player's side.
Once all the players have placed their 2 tokens, we proceed to the combat phase.

Combat phase:
Starting with the player who has the clock on his side of the field, he can make one of the following moves:

Move a soldier to an adjacent square (left or right, up or down) The soldier cannot be moved diagonally.
Attack an enemy square.
End the turn.
Once a player has made a move, it automatically passes to the other player and the clock moves to their side of the field.

Attacking and Defending
When a soldier attacks an enemy square, if there is an enemy soldier on that square, then both fight. The higher number wins.

The losing token "perishes" and is placed on top of its face-up god card [Graveyard]. Tokens that have perished in battle can be consulted by the opponent at any time. If there is a tie, both pieces perish.

The winning soldier must recharge energy, so he places himself at the top of the face-up token column, waiting for his turn to return to action.

—description from the designer

Once your ancestors found or created a source of magic - the exact knowledge of its origin, as far as you know, has long been lost. A small community has developed around the source, which seeks to protect this place and keep it as secret as possible.

Unfortunately, some magical beings — half corporeal, half ethereal — have now tracked down this source. These beings of dubious character, which you call "Djinn", have appeared in various places of the city to dispute your access to the source. You are young members of the Magic Guild, and to prove your abilities, you are tasked with capturing the Djinn so that they can do no harm. You can control them permanently only if you catch them in special Djinn bottles. To seal these bottles, you also need corks made from the bark of a tree near the magic source.

Whichever of you succeeds best in protecting your small town will be accepted into the inner circle of the Magic Guild and will soon be allowed to learn even more secrets...

In Djinn, you take turns moving across a map that shows thirteen locations. These locations are linked to actions where you can get the resources you need and catch the Djinn that are in six locations. In those locations you can do things like receive bottles and corks, collect magical power, buy magical items, hire mages to accompany you, discover secret passages, and more.

In each round, you can reach only one of two or three of the locations, so you must plan carefully to have all the resources you need in time to catch the Djinn. The game ends when all six "Boss Djinn" have been captured and removed from the map, then you score points for all captured Djinn.

-description from developer

DIE-Minions is a strategic dice drafting game where players compete to secure control of four different factions. Each turn, players will move their mad-scientist on the 3x3 board to a new location where they will capture (i.e., draft) 1 die if there are at least 2 present. Based on the die taken, a die from an adjacent location is removed, re-rolled, and placed into the reserve pool. If there are dice in the reserve, the player then place 1 die on any location with an opening for that faction (i.e., color).

Game play continues until each location has 1 die only (9 dice on the board). The player with the highest total influence (sum of dice) in each faction wins control of that faction. Controlling a faction at game end grants a player victory points equal to the sum of the faction dice left on the main board. That is, only the 9 dice left on the board score points for any player.

Players must carefully draft the right dice to gain control of the faction while also ensuring that any faction they control has high scoring dice on the board at the end of the game.

-description from publisher


Truly, it was a GREAT Idea!

World domination was waiting; all you needed was a few extra hands.  What could be the harm in collaborating with those other mad scientists? You’ve got this! Honestly, it was a good idea. Experimental substances, electricity, a little weird science, and presto! a multitude of minions to do your bidding. There’s no such thing as free will, right?

Actually, it was a bad idea. That much applied genius was bound to have unintended consequences. How could you have known that your perfect minions would split into four personalities that refused to get along? It was clearly that other guy’s fault!

Really, it was a terrible idea. Your grand plans must wait while you correct this complication.  But getting back to your proper glory requires sacrifice…

DIE-Minions - it’s not only what you need for victory, but what must be done!
-from the back of the box

Rules.

1. The game is played on an 8x8 board, but it can also be played on boards of different sizes.

2. The first player places 1 stone at their discretion on the empty board.

3. The second player places 2 stones according to a protocol in 2 moves: 1Drop - 1Free.
Drop move: the player places their stone in place of an opponent's stone, moving that opponent's stone to a free adjacent square that is diagonally or orthogonally adjacent.
Free move: the player then places their own stone in a free square that has no stones adjacent diagonally or orthogonally.

4. Players take turns placing their 2 stones according to the 1Drop - 1Free protocol on the board until it is no longer possible to place Free moves. At that point, players proceed only with Drop moves.

5. When placement possibilities are exhausted, the groups sizes for each player are counted. The player with the largest
group wins, in the event of a tie, the size of the second largest group is counted and so on.

"Groups" refer to a single stone or a set of stones of the same color adjacent orthogonally.

—description from the designer

Corporate Life is a worker placement and area control game with special actions. Each turn players choose an ACE card from a hand of 3 and then select 1 of 3 possible actions:

A: Authorized Action - to place or move workers within the organization. 
C: Claim Credit - to score points with the board on your journey to CEO. 
E: Executive Event - Seize opportunities created by well meaning, but ill-advised executives.

Positioning Cubers into key organizational positions grants a player access to department bonuses. Some departments protect your Cubers from actions and events, some augment Claiming Credit, and others alter a player's hand. Leveraging these department actions is key to getting ahead of your competition!

Play continues until one player gains access to the CEO's office (25+ Promotion Points). All players take an even number of turns and the player with the most promotion points is appointed the new CEO and wins the game.

This is not a business simulation! It is a lighthearted poke at office politics, bizarre corporate structures, and the underhanded action of those that subscribe to the lifestyle of Corporate Life.
-description from publisher


Welcome to Corporate Life…

You’ve always known you should be in charge. When it comes to directing others, Hollywood’s titans would be wise to seek your advice. That’s why you joined the Inc.Co LLC team - to seize the CEO reins. Unfortunately, your understanding of how it’s supposed to be and that of the Board of Directors is a wee bit out of alignment. Somehow, you’ve landed in a mailroom job. But things are about to change. All you need is the right Cubers (Cubical Workers) in the right position and the company will be yours!

'Corporate Life is a game of competitive manipulation and control. Players vie to maneuver Cubers into key department positions, seize credit for the work of others, and pursuit of that coveted CEO promotion.
- from back of box

Do you dare to enter the temple? Thrilling physical action and blazing bouts of card play await you! In this race for fortune and glory, two teams are pitted against each other—Indiana Jones versus his bitter rival Belloq! Gain the most points by outmaneuvering your opponents in laughter-filled, out-of-your-seat challenges!

Players compete in different timed events in dexterity challenges, using props from Indiana Jones movies!

-description from publisher

The Franciscan Diamond is an 18 card trick-taking game played with an asymmetric deck of 4 suits. Each suit has a different number of cards.  The game starts with players taking a hidden role and proceeds over 8 rounds.

Each round begins with 3 draft passes where cards are exchanged between all of the players. After the drafts, play consists of tricks where players attempt to capture cards aligned to their secret role while avoiding collecting cards aligned to their role's nemesis. To help keep roles secret, scores in all four suits are kept for each player until the end of the game.

At the end of the game, players score points only for their role cards and lose points for any their nemesis cards obtained.  Cards acquired from the other two suits do not gain or lose the player any points. The player with the highest total score wins.

The Franciscan Diamond requires players to play differently based on their assigned role. It is important to try to uncover the roles of others so that the drafts can ensure the right cards end up with the right players to create tricks that are favorable to a player's goals. This manipulation must then be balanced against keeping your secret role hidden. The result of this mix is an unusual trick-taking game that fans of noir mystery can enjoy.
-description from publisher

The Crime of the Century…

…is about to be committed.  A Master Thief has set her eyes on The Franciscan Diamond and is plotting to steal it, but an equally talented Private Eye is on her trail. Seeking to distract the gumshoe and working her own angle is the Femme Fatale. But it’s no cake walk for her either because The Cops are hounding her every move, all while trying to avoid being played the fools by the Master Thief. Who will emerge victorious from this caper is a mystery!

'The Franciscan Diamond is an 18-card trick-taking game starring four classic characters of a Noir Mystery: the Master Thief, the Private Eye, the Femme Fatale, and The Cops. Players start the game with a secret role and aim to win tricks that score their objective cards while avoiding collecting cards linked to their nemesis. After 8 scenes, the case is closed and the player that best played their role emerges as the victor!
- from back of box

Unleash your inner warrior and master the art of combat in Martial Clash, a thrilling 2-player board game that combines strategy, skill, and heart-pounding action. Players choose their martial artist character, each with unique stats and techniques, and engage in a fast-paced battle to be the first to claim 2 win tokens. Experience intense rock-paper-scissors style movement phases, strategic dice rolling for combos and counters, and use powerful secret techniques to turn the tide of battle.

To win a player must get 2 WIN tokens, a player gets a WIN token each time the character health of the other player go down to 0.

Game occurs in 2 phases: Movement phase and Combo phase.

Movement phase, players pick a card from the movement cards (hit, block or grab) (rock, paper, scisors mechanic)

The player who won the movement phase becomes the atacker and starts the combo phase.

In the Combo phase, the atacker do a re-roll and lock of a  pool of d6 trying to get the right combinations to do differents techniques.

-description from designer

Kitten Kingdoms is a delightful and engaging card game that transports players into a whimsical world where adorable kittens rule over various realms. There are four distinct factions: Fluffington Aristocats, Purrville Innovators, Clawtopia Rogues, and Whiskeria Ambassadors. Each faction offers unique abilities and strategies, allowing players to craft their own style of play and outwit their opponents.

Fluffington: Focuses on drawing cards
Purrville: Focuses on rotating kittens
Whiskeria: Focuses on playing recruitment cards
Clawtopia: Focuses on disruption and chaos in the game

This game is a deck-building style game where players build decks of cards to recruit their own or opponents' kittens with a unique rotation mechanic and recruitment mechanic.

There are a few types of cards in the game:

Kitten Heroes - These are the cards you are trying to recruit.
Kitten Lords - These are powerful leaders of the factions that give high scores and excellent bonuses for those players that recruit them.
Recruiters - These attach to Kitten Heroes and give bonuses.
Motivators - These are cards you play during your turn to motivate kittens to join your cause.
Pounce - These cards can be played at any time and are usually for disrupting your opponent.

The game ends when 6 of the 8 Kitten Lords are recruited. Scores are then tallied, and the player with the highest recruitment score wins.

Games usually last 30-35 minutes but this is highly variable as 6 of the Lords need to be found.

Trick of Chicken is a trick-taking game for 3 to 4 players.  The game uses an irregular deck of 3 suits.  It is a must-follow game, but the winner will be the person who played the lowest ranked card in the suit with the highest sum in the trick - with some special cards, such as the 2 which doubles (x2) other cards of its suit.

Cards from tricks are placed around a central disc showing the three suits.  Specifically, the winner will take their card face down in front of themselves, but the other cards from the trick go face down next to the wheel in front of the spot for the suit which won the trick.   The winner of the last trick takes all of the cards from the sector of the wheel which matches the card they won the trick with, setting them in front of themselves face up.

Players score points for face down and face up cards. The game takes place over several rounds and the player with the highest total score wins.

Atmosfear, the iconic horror-themed board game, has returned in its 30th Anniversary Edition, and it's as thrilling and immersive as ever! This modernized version of the classic game comes with updated components (through the Kickstarter campaign) and a nostalgic nod to the original, making it a must-have for both longtime fans and newcomers alike.

Components:
The 30th Anniversary Edition of Atmosfear comes with high-quality components that are visually stunning and tactilely pleasing. The game includes a beautifully illustrated game board, six character pawns to collect keys for, multiple types of cards (Time, Fatez and Chance), and 2x 6D with the Gatekeeper's head in them! The game now comes with a QR code to find the video of the game on Vimeo instead of a VHS or DVD featuring the iconic Gatekeeper, who sets the tone for the game with his sinister presence. The components are durable and well-designed, adding to the overall immersion and enjoyment of the game.

Gameplay:
The gameplay of Atmosfear remains true to the original, with some modern updates that add to the excitement. Players take on the roles of six different characters, each with their own strengths and weaknesses, as they navigate through the various regions of the board, trying to collect keys and make their way to the center to face the Gatekeeper. The video is used as a timer, adding a sense of urgency to the game, and the Gatekeeper's appearances on the screen are both thrilling and chilling (and loud!).

One of the standout features of the 30th Anniversary Edition is the addition of new event cards, which bring a fresh level of unpredictability to the game. These cards can affect players in various ways, such as forcing them to swap places, lose turns, or face challenges that can alter the course of the game. The combination of the video, cards, and unique character abilities creates a dynamic and engaging gameplay experience that keeps players on their toes and eager for more.

Theme and Atmosphere:
Atmosfear is all about creating a spooky and immersive atmosphere, and the 30th Anniversary Edition does not disappoint. The game's theme of horror and suspense is brought to life through the video, which features the iconic Gatekeeper, who taunts and challenges players throughout the game. The game board is richly illustrated with dark and eerie artwork that adds to the overall ambiance. The combination of the components, gameplay, and theme work together seamlessly to create an immersive and thrilling experience that will keep players on the edge of their seats.

Fun Factor:
Atmosfear 30th Anniversary Edition is an absolute blast to play. The combination of the video, event cards, and unique character abilities create a highly interactive and unpredictable gameplay experience that keeps players engaged and entertained from start to finish. The sense of urgency created by the timer adds to the excitement, and the overall atmosphere of the game is thrilling and immersive. The game also encourages player interaction, with opportunities for strategic decision-making, alliances, and betrayals, making for a highly enjoyable and memorable gaming experience.

Overall:
Atmosfear 30th Anniversary Edition is a fantastic board game that successfully revitalizes the classic horror-themed game for a modern audience. The components, gameplay, and immersive atmosphere make for an engaging and thrilling experience that will keep players coming back for more. Whether you're a longtime fan of the original or new to the world of Atmosfear, this anniversary edition is a must-have addition to your board game collection. Get ready to face your fears and embrace the darkness with Atmosfear 30th Anniversary Edition!

SOE: Lysander is the first of a new set of low-cost, book-based games in the "Special Missions" series that put you directly into the cockpit.

Your mission is as a pilot in Great Britain's most secret aviation unit, "A" Flight of RAF 161 Squadron (Special Duties). You will fly Special Operations Executive (SOE) agents, wireless operators, saboteurs, assassins, political figures, heads of the French Resistance, and others into and out of German-occupied France during the darkest times of the Second World War.

By moonlight, you will navigate your Westland Lysander Mk. IIIA (SD) aircraft across the Channel and over occupied France to find a distant landing zone deep behind enemy lines. You will encounter flak, German patrols, small arms fire, night fighters, and the constant threat of being discovered by the Gestapo.

SOE: Lysander is in the solitaire narrative style and with a small table footprint and easy-to-learn rules. While the gameplay is designed to be straightforward, the challenges you will face are extensive. Your goal is to keep your assigned Circuits supplied -- these are underground partisan cells in the French Resistance. Your operations begin in April 1943 and your mission continues until just before D-Day.

The odds of survival are slim. Do you have what it takes?

Available through Amazon (worldwide): https://www.amazon.com/dp/B0C9SLG2ND/

The boxed set of game maps and assets (game counters and chits) is also available from Blue Panther!
https://www.bluepantherllc.com/products/soe-lysander

—description from designer

In the tactical co-operative game The Last Spell: The Board Game, a tabletop adaptation of Ishtar Games' video game of the same name, you are a hardened warrior whose only purpose in life is to desperately defend the last of the mages while trying to cast "the last spell" and banish all magic from this world and maybe save us all. Maybe.

The game is set in a dark fantasy, post-apocalyptic world in which you have to carefully manage the scarce resources at your disposal to survive long enough. Gameplay revolves around three cycles of day and night in which players use daylight hours to bolster the game economy, fortify defenses against nocturnal invaders, and upgrade their heroes' equipment to unlock more power.

You can choose to play single scenarios or embark on a campaign that challenges you with increasing levels of difficulty. With a plethora of weapons and abilities at your disposal across multiple plays, there's always something new to explore — and for the ultimate test of your strategic prowess, witness the fiery destruction of your city in the face of overwhelming odds.

—description from the publisher

The Prisoner’s Dilemma is the most famous conundrum in Game Theory. Two criminals are caught by the police for a minor crime. They are suspected of a major crime which, if convicted, would put them behind bars for a long time indeed. The police separate the two partners in crime and offer them a bargain. If they betray the other prisoner, they will be released. If both stay silent the police will only be able convict them of their minor crime. If they both take the offer and betray each other they will both serve a long sentence. In Prisoner’s Trilemma: Game Theory in Action, players are presented with a variety of moral dilemmas where they have three possible choices to make. Players can choose to cooperate, betray or compromise to make the best of a difficult situation.

OBJECTIVE – The objective of Prisoner’s Trilemma is to work through moral quandaries each with three possible choices presented to the players scoring points based on the outcomes.
GAME PLAY – In each of five rounds, players are presented with a moral trilemma. Players play cards from their hand representing the degree to which they cooperate, betray or compromise in the situation. Payoff cards are revealed in each round which indicates points earned from the decisions the players make.
GAME END AND WINNING – Prisoner’s Trilemma ends after five rounds, when the players considered five trilemmas.
THEME – Game Theory Exploration

—description from the designer

Easter is finally here and the annual egg-hunt is a long-awaited favourite for both young and old. Sharpen your sight, be the fastest egg hunter and above all - loot the most candy. Let the adventures found in Easter Quest begin!

In Easter Quest, each turn begins by revealing a card that depict an egg that matches an egg token somewhere in the forest (on the game board). All eggs appear to look the same but they actually differ slightly. The faster you locate the right egg token, the more likely you are to reach it before anyone else.

The game comes with both a basic and an advanced variant.

In the basic variant (children's variant) you will also need luck with the roll the dice and choose smart paths to be successful.

In the advanced variant (family variant) you need to find the shortest path AND count the correct number of steps, before anyone else, to be successful. Do not forget that you can "warp" by leaving the game board at one end and enter it at the other side.

The first player to reach the egg gets to loot it by drawing a candy token from the bag. The player with most candy win (as in real life).

The perfect game to play during Easter, or on any other day of the year.

Unlock! is a cooperative card game inspired by escape rooms that uses a simple system which allows you to search scenes, combine objects, and solve riddles. Play Unlock! to embark on great adventures, while seated at a table using only cards and a companion app that can provide clues, check codes, monitor time remaining, etc.

Professor Noside's Animal-O-Matic - "The Animal-O-Matic transfers you into the body of any animal. It's not dangerous, I'm telling you! Will you stop moving James!"

An included ten-card tutorial allows you to learn how to play without reading the game rules. Note: Unlock! requires a free application to be downloaded from the App Store or Google Play. Once downloaded, an internet connection is not required during game play.

The follow-up to the highly-rated Monster Hunter World board game, Monster Hunter World Iceborne: The Board Game is a cooperative arena combat game for 1-4 players bursting with all new quests, exciting new gameplay, and a whole new line-up of MASSIVE monsters to hunt!

A mysterious song is echoing over the New World and causing the mass migration of Legiana. Now, the Research Commission needs YOU to investigate. Become a hunter of the Fifth Fleet and head to an uncharted arctic tundra where unknown threats roam wild. Protect the new Seliana basecamp from monsters unlike any you’ve faced before. Claim monster loot from your successful hunts to craft awesome new equipment, so you can hunt bigger and badder beasts until you’ve mastered Hoarfrost Reach!

				
				
					How it PlaysLike World, Iceborne will plunge you into an open world where monsters won’t sit back and be hunted. Every fight is a boss fight. The monster controls the flow of combat, pushing you and your party to the limit — and each monster is wildly different. It’s crush-or-be-crushed with beasts as mobile as these!

Choose your hunter based on their unique weapon and playstyle. Pick which infamous monster you’ll be hunting across the ice. Track the creature in a quest driven by your decisions, avoiding pitfalls and collecting bonus resources to help you in the challenges ahead.

Then dive into heart-pounding, card-driven combat where teamwork, positioning, and stamina are key, targeting the monster parts you need for the equipment you want to craft — without getting wiped out!


     Play multiple epic campaigns with different combos of hunters, monsters, and equipment. The more monsters you slay, the better the weapons you can craft, the bigger the monsters you can hunt!
     Short on time? Every monster comes with single session arena quests, so you can plunge right into combat
     Want to play solo? No problem! Monster Hunter World Iceborne: The Board Game includes solo mode


				
				
					What’s New?Iceborne is a standalone board game that takes the highly-rated Monster Hunter World engine and introduces some game-changing Iceborne twists. Hunt a whole new roster of monsters who hit even harder when they’re angry. Navigate frozen terrain. Use your Clutch Claw to get close to the beasts. Find bonus info when tracking to help in the fight ahead. Manage your stamina in a new way. And brace yourself for brutal wind-up attacks!

A new threat lurks in the land of Arzium. Ember zombies swarm from volcanic lands to the south, their charcoal bodies the walking hives of evil fire fairies. The closest haven is the city of Eastrey, where a powerful artifact protects the inhabitants. You must travel across the desert and the plains, over mountains and through red canyons, helping wandering creatures of every shape and size to the safety of the city.

In Creature Caravan, players build a card tableau of creatures while traveling through a magnificent and dangerous land. Players take turns simultaneously, placing dice on actions on their cards, moving their caravan on the map, and playing new creature cards. Players also compete to trade goods and rare coins in a shared market, search the mysterious white towers, and fight ember zombies as they travel. The game ends when one player reaches Eastrey. The player with the most points wins.

The game includes 134 cards, each with a unique illustration and combination of actions and abilities. Simultaneous gameplay allows one to four players to play together without increasing the game's length, with the Wanderers expansion (sold separately or comes inside the Deluxe Edition) allowing for up to six players.

—description from the publisher

A survival/strategy board game that takes place during the last Ice Age. Players navigate the board and participate in the actions at their leisure. But like life, the game can be unpredictable and force you into action and even take everything you have accumulated away from you. Work with the other players or go it alone as you fight for survival in a world full of prehistoric beasts such as woolly mammoths and sabre-toothed cats.

—description from the designer

Star Wars: Rivals is an expandable card game in which the light and dark sides of the Force face off, with each player building a squadron from characters throughout different eras of the Star Wars universe.

Star Wars: Rivals – Series 1 – Premier Set includes four characters — Luke Skywalker and Commander Cody vs. Darth Vader and Asajj Ventress — 14 action cards, 18 tokens and markers, 12 location cards, and a prism die. Each character has three unique action cards, and players use their characters to try to claim location cards.

This set is playable on its own, but players can also create larger squadrons, whether for the light or dark side, by using new characters present in character booster packs.

S.U.N. is a strategy board game played with cards and tokens.

Each player represents one of the species of the space federation that competes with the others to be the most technologically advanced without open hostilities. The first player to reach 21 technology points wins.

It combines the obtaining of resources to build technologies and get the points to win, with an important component of negotiation with the rest of the players. The diplomatic proposals are advantages that you can obtain, but they have to be voted among the players for their approval, so you will have to negotiate to convince them. You will have the opportunity to be President, or to become a despotic Emperor.

You can keep your promises, or not. And you can play Subterfuge behind the backs of your peers...

You decide the reputation you want to have in the Federation.

—description from the designer

Race against each other to SLAP a match between a card and spoken word!

Taco Cat Goat Cheese Pizza: Easter Edition is filled to the brim with hand-slapping mayhem! As in Snap and Dobble, each player places a card from their hand face up into a community pile while saying taco/cat/goat/cheese/pizza in player sequence. When the card matches the mantra — boom! — everyone slaps their hand on the deck, with the last one to slap picking up the cards. Whoever rids themselves of cards first wins!

For extra fun, special action cards – the bunny-eared gorilla, chick-costumed narwhal, and egg-collecting groundhog — force players to make certain gestures before racing to slap the deck.

—description from the publisher

The citizens of Burano, a picturesque island in Venice, are known for their creative flair in decorating their houses, making them a popular attraction for tourists and locals alike.

In the roll-and-write version of Walking in Burano, the houses are painted. Players select dice of different colors to decorate the houses with plants, curtains, chimneys and, of course, the annoying cats. This version maintains the neat scoring from the original game and adds a unique gaming experience of roll and write.

Based on the different decorations on the houses, tourists and inhabitants evaluate the players with points. At the end of the game, the player with the most points wins.

—description from the publisher

A free Print and Play solitaire game based on the cold war. Perfect for educational purpose or just to have fun!

In this game, you are the leader of one of these two superpowers, and all you have is your strategy and instincts to help protect and lead your nation to glory. Can you outwit your opponent and come out on top?

The fate of your nation rests in your hands.

The game takes place in 18 rounds that retrace 18 real events during the cold war. Each event is represented by a card that describes the details of the event. The objective of the game is avoid a nuclear holocaust and, at the end of 18 rounds, being the nation with the highest dice value in at least two areas of influence and win the cold war.

—description from the designer

Step into the role of a space orchestra manager with Philharmonix, the worker placement game that combines music and sci-fi in an out-of-this-world experience!

Send your orchestra on missions to perform on different planets, strategically acquire new talented musicians, and train them to reach their full potential. Please the patrons that sponsor these concerts with your performances, and watch out for unexpected challenges along the way.

In Philharmonix, you play as a space orchestra manager, trying to become the most prestigious orchestra in the Malaya sector.
Each turn, you will select one of the 6 major actions or the basic move action. The basic action is to move across the Malayan planets or to gain money. The major actions include: recruiting musicians, training musicians & conductors, creating symphonies, performing Symphonies, gaining patrons, and expanding your knowledge and experience. During your turn, you can also perform free actions to manipulate your gameplay.

Each action consumes action points which would be randomized every round and could consume more action points if the action is
occupied. Thus, players need to be efficient in selecting their actions.

Players can gain Prestige in many ways, but mainly from performing Symphonies and recording “Records” (objectives). Other
methods of gaining Prestige are region majority, collecting musicians, and claiming patrons.

The game ends after five rounds and the player with the most Prestige is the winner of the game and is proclaimed the best space orchestra manager!

—description from the publisher

FAST, MERCILESS ADVENTURE AWAITS!

Assemble your team of rag-tag heroes, defy all logic and warnings, and head into the abysmal world of Aezmae to defeat the evil Maedorn in one final, epic showdown. Labyrinth Adventures is a dungeon-crawl adventure gamebook series for 1-4 heroes ready to embark upon the adventure of a lifetime!

DELVE INTO:

â˜‘ï¸ BRUTALLY RELENTLESS COMBAT: Hit first, hit hard! Build your defences to survive!

â˜‘ï¸ QUICK PLAY THAT'S STRATEGIC & TACTICAL: A low-rule set makes gameplay quick and satisfying while remaining deep. Each session lasts 1 hour.

â˜‘ï¸ VICIOUS PERILS AND EPIC REWARDS: Each step might be your last. Will you find a trove of riches or meet your demise?

â˜‘ï¸ ENGROSSING LORE: Immersive backstories, terrifying enemy stats, and fantasy tales that draw you into the darkness!

â˜‘ï¸ SELF-GENERATING DUNGEONS: Watch mesmerizing labyrinths unfold through simple D6 rolls.

â˜‘ï¸ UNIQUE CHARACTERS EVERY TIME:  Specialized upgrades give you the power to evolve your hero the way you choose.

Tres Reinos ("Three Kingdoms") is a trick-taking game in which players often will have to team up with other players to reach victory.

In each round, starting with the opening player, each player will first play one of their cards and then decide whether or not to draw a mercenary card to join their force. When everyone has done so, check to see which faction has the most power, as in this trick-taking game it is not the highest card that wins, but the faction.

Once checked, whoever has the most powerfull within that faction will first choose one of the two rewards available during this round.

At the end of the game the points are counted taking into account the conquered kingdom cards with their modifiers, the personal kingdom card with its own bonuses and penalties. The winner is the one with the most points.

Tres Reinos is a trick-taking game, in which players will have to know when to be opportunistic and when it is not in their interest to win a trick.

In the hot desert sand, not far from the oldest pyramid in the world, you end up at an unknown excavation site. Where initially only worthless chunks of stone and broken vessels appear, you will soon come across more valuable finds. At the same time, you are trying to place these artifacts in a common collection in order to profitably transfer them to the local museum. Whoever manages to do this best is crowned the most successful archaeologist.

On your turn, you can either

     play exactly 2 cards from your hand, or
     draw as many cards as you like, respecting your hand limit (max. 5)


Try to play the cards strategically in the common display to reach a card value of 15 to gain prestige. The player with the most prestige wins.

Paneveggio will immerse you in 1700 close to the Paneveggio Forest where generations of renowned luthiers such as Amati, Stradivarius or Guardani took the precious wood to build the famous violins we still hear about today.
Players will embody young luthiers who are launching their own workshop after leaving their mentor.
They will try to earn as much Violin points (VP) as possible and offer their most beautiful work of art to prestigious musicians of that time by alternating work sessions and rest.
The game is based on a musical score mechanics, the notes are then representing planned actions.

—description from the publisher

In Dead Center, you must kill twelve zombies surrounding your 3x3 cabin before the deck runs out. You do this by playing cards into piles within the cabin to attack adjacent zombies. The power and precision of your attacks is determined not by the card you played, but by the two other cards on the same line.

Dead Center is a solo game playable with a deck of regular playing cards, with rules created by Wil Su and made available free online as part of his "Isaludo" series.

In Foursquare, you are the mayor of the fictional Flavortown, a trendy neighborhood known for being the birthplace of cutting-edge restaurants. New restaurants (cards) will be placed one at a time in a 4x4 grid. Placing the highest or lowest card in a
row or column causes all other cards in that row or column to flip over, as other restaurants go out of business or try to challenge the newcomer. Your task is to end up with sixteen open restaurants in your city, while preventing too many from being closed at once.

As part of the Isaludo collection, the rules can be found in this forum thread.

You are Sheryl Holmes, terror of the first-grade playground. Known far and wide (at least three schools over!) for your observational skills, you have a reputation of being unstoppable at hide-and-seek.
In Hide and Seek, you will be placing cards around a grid of hidden playmates, trying to match their suit. You may reveal anyone’s identity at any time, and you score if the cards you placed match the playmates’ suit. The more playmates you find, the easier it is to narrow down the identities of the rest, so you must strike a delicate balance between guessing too early versus too late.

As part of the Isaludo collection, the rules can be found in this forum thread.
